what-makes-claude-code-different.title: What Makes Claude Code Different?
what-makes-claude-code-different.intro: If you've been using ChatGPT or Claude in your browser, you already know how powerful AI can be. But here's the thing—every time Claude gives you code, you still have to copy it, paste it into a file, save it, and figure out where everything goes. What if Claude could just... do it for you?

sections.heading: The Browser Experience vs. Claude Code
sections.content:
When you use Claude in the browser, it's like having a really smart advisor. You ask a question, it gives you an answer. You need code, it writes code. But you're still the one doing all the manual work—creating files, organizing folders, running commands.

**Claude Code flips the script.** It operates directly in your terminal, which means it can:

- **Create files** on your behalf
- **Edit code** across your entire project
- **Run scripts** and terminal commands
- **Build entire projects** through natural language

You're no longer coding *with* Claude—you're coding *through* natural language.

sections.heading: What This Looks Like in Practice
sections.content:
Think about it: instead of asking "Can you write me a React component?" and then spending 10 minutes figuring out where to put the files, you just say:

```
Build me a React component for a login form
```

And watch it happen in real-time. Claude creates the files, writes the code, and even sets up the folder structure. You just describe what you want.

terminal-refresher.title: A Quick Terminal Refresher
terminal-refresher.intro: If you've never used a terminal before, don't stress. Here are the only commands you need to know to get started with Claude Code.

sections.heading: The Three Commands You Need
sections.content:
That's right—just three:

**`ls`** — Lists everything in your current folder

**`cd [folder name]`** — Changes directory (moves you into a folder)

**`mkdir [folder name]`** — Makes a new directory (creates a folder)

That's it. Seriously.

sections.heading: Putting It Together
sections.content:
Here's how it works in practice:

```bash
ls                    # See what's in your current location
cd Documents          # Move into your Documents folder
mkdir my-project      # Create a new folder called "my-project"
cd my-project         # Move into that new folder
ls                    # Should be empty since you just created it
```

Once you're inside the folder where you want to work, you're ready to start Claude.

sections.heading: Understanding Sessions
sections.content:
**One important thing to understand:** Each Claude Code session is independent. When you close your terminal or type `exit`, that session ends.

The next time you run `claude`, it's a fresh start—Claude won't remember your previous conversation or the permissions you granted.

Your *files* persist (they're saved on your computer), but the conversation context doesn't. This is actually helpful—each session is a clean slate.

starting-claude-code.title: Starting Claude Code
starting-claude-code.intro: With your terminal open and navigated to your project folder, you're just one command away from building with AI.

sections.heading: The Magic Command
sections.content:
Type:

```bash
claude
```

Hit enter, and you should see something like:

```
Welcome back! Using model: [your model]
Plan: [your plan type]
```

That's it—you're in. Claude is now ready to receive instructions and start building.

sections.heading: What Happens Next
sections.content:
When Claude starts, it automatically scans your current directory to understand your project structure. If you're in an empty folder, it knows you're starting fresh. If you're in an existing project, it understands the codebase.

You'll see a prompt where you can type your requests. Think of it as a conversation—you describe what you want, and Claude figures out how to build it.

building-portfolio-part-1.title: Your First Project: Finding Inspiration
building-portfolio-part-1.intro: Let's build something real. For this tutorial, we're creating a personal portfolio website—and we're going to use visual inspiration to guide Claude.

sections.heading: Step 1: Find Your Inspiration
sections.content:
Here's a pro tip: Claude isn't a designer, and honestly, neither am I. So before we start prompting, let's find a website we actually like.

- Go browse some portfolio sites
- Look at personal websites from people in your industry
- Find one that resonates with you—something where you think "I want my site to feel like *that*"

For this example, let's say you found a clean, modern portfolio with scrollable sections, a strong hero image, and clear calls-to-action.

sections.heading: Step 2: Screenshot Everything
sections.content:
This is where it gets good. Take screenshots of every section of the site you like.

**On Mac:** `Command + Shift + 4`, then drag to select the area

**On Windows:** `Windows + Shift + S` to use Snipping Tool

Screenshot the header. Screenshot the about section. Screenshot the portfolio grid. Screenshot the footer. Get everything.

**Why screenshots?** Claude can't browse live websites, but it *can* analyze images you provide. By giving it screenshots, Claude can understand the layout, structure, and visual hierarchy—then use that as a template for what it builds for you.

This screenshot workflow is your way of showing Claude what you want.

keyTakeaways: Find visual inspiration before you start prompting
Screenshot every section of designs you like

building-portfolio-part-2.title: Your First Project: Writing Prompts & Permissions
building-portfolio-part-2.intro: Now that you have your inspiration screenshots, let's write your first prompt and handle Claude's permission system.

sections.heading: Step 3: Write Your First Prompt
sections.content:
Back in Claude Code, let's write a prompt. Here's a framework that works:

```
I need a personal/professional website to act as my portfolio, housing my work, 
my career background, and showcasing me in a good light.

Please build this out using the screenshots I provide as a template.

Anywhere a picture is needed for now, just put a placeholder.
```

Notice a few things about this prompt:

1. **It's high-level.** We're not micromanaging every detail yet.
2. **It states the goal clearly.** Claude knows this is a portfolio site.
3. **It anticipates problems.** We don't have photos ready, so we tell Claude to use placeholders.

sections.heading: Step 4: Add Your Screenshots
sections.content:
Here's the magic part. Find your screenshots (they're probably on your Desktop or in Recent files), select all of them, and literally **drag them into your terminal window**.

Yes, really. Just drag and drop.

You'll see the file paths appear in your prompt. Now hit enter.

sections.heading: Step 5: Handle the Permission Prompts
sections.content:
Claude Code respects your privacy. It's going to ask for permission before it reads files or makes changes. You'll see prompts like:

```
Do you want to proceed?
1. Yes
2. Yes, allow reading from [folder] during this session
3. No
```

**Always pick option 2.** This tells Claude "yes, and don't ask me again for this type of action during our session." Otherwise, you'll be clicking "yes" every 30 seconds.

**Important:** These permissions are session-level only. If you close your terminal and start a new `claude` session, it'll ask for permissions again. Nothing persists between sessions.

Same goes for editing files—pick the option that auto-allows edits during the session.

sections.heading: Step 6: Watch It Work
sections.content:
Now sit back and watch Claude do its thing. You'll see it:

- Create a to-do list for itself
- Check off items as it completes them
- Generate HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files
- Build out the structure section by section

When it's done, it'll typically ask if you want to open the site in your browser. Say yes. See what you've got.

plan-mode.title: Leveling Up: Plan Mode
plan-mode.intro: Plan Mode is one of the most powerful features in Claude Code, and it's what separates quick prototypes from quality work.

sections.heading: What Is Plan Mode?
sections.content:
Think about writing an essay. You don't just start writing and hope for the best. You outline first. You draft. You revise.

Plan Mode makes Claude do the same thing. Instead of just diving into code, it:

1. Creates an architecture
2. Maps out every step
3. Asks clarifying questions
4. *Then* builds

The result? Better code, fewer errors, and a structure that actually makes sense.

sections.heading: How to Activate Plan Mode
sections.content:
Hold **Shift** and press **Tab**. You'll see the mode indicator change to "plan mode on."

You can also cycle through modes by pressing Shift+Tab multiple times:
- Accept edits
- Plan mode on
- Other settings

sections.heading: When to Use Plan Mode
sections.content:
Use plan mode when:

- Starting a new project from scratch
- Building something complex
- Working on features that require strategic thinking
- Dealing with anything that involves psychology, persuasion, or user experience

For example, if you wanted to optimize your portfolio to convert visitors into clients, you might prompt:

```
This looks fantastic. However, I really need people to feel a large amount of trust 
in me after they view my website. It's important that people feel the urge to work 
with me after going through these sections.

If they are a decision maker, I need them to feel confident in my abilities.
If they are a consumer, I need them to feel connected to my story.

Please edit the content accordingly.
```

In plan mode, Claude will think through the psychological principles involved, create a strategy, possibly ask you clarifying questions, and *then* execute.

adding-real-content.title: Adding Real Content
adding-real-content.intro: Once you have your basic structure, it's time to make it yours with real content and images.

sections.heading: Pulling From Your Online Presence
sections.content:
Claude can read public websites to learn about you. Try a prompt like:

```
This is fantastic. Now let's work on filling in the page with my actual information.

Please use these links to do this:
- https://linkedin.com/in/yourprofile
- https://instagram.com/yourhandle  
- https://yourwebsite.com
```

Claude will pull relevant information—your bio, your work history, your projects—and populate your portfolio accordingly.

**Note:** Some sites like LinkedIn may block scraping. If that happens, Claude will let you know and work with what it can access.

sections.heading: Adding Your Images
sections.content:
Want to add your actual photos? Same process as before—find the images on your computer and drag them into the terminal:

```
This is great. Please now input photos using the images I provide.

[drag images here]
```

Claude will place them in the appropriate sections, resize as needed, and update the code.

pro-tips.title: Pro Tips for Better Results
pro-tips.intro: These tips will help you get better results faster and avoid common frustrations.

sections.heading: Give Positive Feedback
sections.content:
This isn't just being nice—it actually helps. When you tell Claude "This is fantastic" or "Great work so far," you're confirming that the approach was correct and signaling what you value.

Within your session, this helps Claude understand it's on the right track and should continue in that direction.

```
This is fantastic. Now let's...
```

**Note:** This doesn't "train" Claude or persist across sessions—each new session starts fresh. But in the moment, it's like giving a collaborator real-time feedback so they know what's working.

sections.heading: Start High-Level, Then Get Specific
sections.content:
Don't dump every requirement into your first prompt. Start with the big picture, let Claude build something, then iterate with specific feedback:

1. **First prompt:** "Build me a portfolio website using these screenshots"
2. **Second prompt:** "Make the navigation sticky at the top"
3. **Third prompt:** "Change the hero section headline to..."

This iterative approach often gets better results than trying to specify everything upfront.

sections.heading: Watch the Token Count
sections.content:
Claude uses tokens to process your requests. Tokens are sub-word units—a word like "portfolio" might be 2-3 tokens, while common words like "the" are typically one token.

The key thing to know: the longer your conversation, the more tokens it uses. You might see a colored indicator (orange, blue, pink) showing your usage.

If Claude asks to "clear context," **say yes**. This compacts your conversation history to save tokens without losing the important context. It's like hitting "summarize" on your chat history so you can keep working without hitting limits.

sections.heading: Keep an Eye on Changes
sections.content:
As Claude works, scroll through your terminal to see what it's changing. You'll see red (removed) and green (added) text showing exactly what's being modified.

This helps you:

- Understand your own project structure
- Catch anything you don't want
- Learn how the code actually works

permissions-and-troubleshooting.title: Permissions & Troubleshooting
permissions-and-troubleshooting.intro: Understanding permission messages and knowing how to troubleshoot common issues will save you time and frustration.

sections.heading: Common Permission Messages
sections.content:
**"Do you want to proceed?"**
Claude wants to do something (read a file, make an edit). Pick option 2 to auto-allow that type of action for the session.

**"Clear context and auto accept edits?"**
Your conversation is getting long. Clearing context compresses the history to save tokens. Say yes.

**"Open in browser?"**
Claude wants to show you the result. Click tab to auto-complete the command, then enter.

sections.heading: Troubleshooting Common Issues
sections.content:
**Claude isn't making changes I can see:**
Try refreshing your browser. Changes might be saved but not reflected yet.

**The layout looks wrong:**
Describe specifically what's wrong: "The images are overlapping the text" or "I want all sections on one scrollable page, not separate pages."

**Claude stopped in the middle of something:**
Just prompt it to continue: "Please continue" or "Keep going."

**I'm out of tokens:**
You've hit your usage limit for the period. Depending on your plan, this resets after a certain time. Consider upgrading if you're building a lot.

what-you-can-build.title: What You Can Build
what-you-can-build.intro: Once you get comfortable with Claude Code, the possibilities are genuinely impressive. Here's what you can create.

sections.heading: Beyond Portfolio Websites
sections.content:
Once you get comfortable, the possibilities are wild:

- **Full websites** with multiple pages
- **Web applications** with databases
- **Data analysis pipelines**
- **Automation scripts**
- **APIs and backends**
- **Literally anything** you can describe

I've had Claude Code sessions where a single Claude worked for **40+ minutes straight**, debugging deployment issues, fixing databases, and iterating until everything was perfect.

sections.heading: The Bottom Line
sections.content:
Claude Code isn't just a fancier chatbot. It's a fundamental shift in how we build things. You're no longer learning syntax and debugging semicolons—you're describing what you want and watching it materialize.

Is it perfect? No. Sometimes the design needs work. Sometimes you need to clarify what you meant. But the iteration cycle is *so fast* that it doesn't matter. You can go from idea to working prototype in the time it used to take to just set up your development environment.

So open that terminal. Type `claude`. And start building.
